rule: The output must include words such as "thou," "thee," and "hath" as part of its vocabulary to maintain authenticity to the period's linguistic style.
input: Compose a short tale of a forlorn prince.
output:
Once upon a time in lands afar there reigned over a realm a princely squire, his name was Edmund of Eldorath. The years had passed and yet he did not change from lad to man and still walked clad in gowns. Ere long the day came when th' old king fell ill as a grave man doth fearfully suffer, and Edmund could see that much needed change should be wrought.

Thither sought this princeling of course for grace, with which they would replace his sire's throne, to reign over Eldorath upon his passing. For many an hour Edmund sought the halls where he once roamed as a boy, seeking solace in memories past - but all was still quiet save for those that had seen doom alight on his father.

Then one foreboding morn Edmund did take his stand upon a cliff's brink and surveyed with care a wide and wild countryside beneath. There at last did grief give way to hope from the sight of which a prince would surely rule in noble fashion - as he would see fit by his own hand.
Thus it was that his soul would find its place anew amidst this land, through deeds done most wise. For Edmund did remember then with force and clarity what love and courage had once been bestowed to his heart, and so they set forth as one upon a quest in ways both noble and new.
